html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Italic *klaudō, from Proto-Indo-European *kleh₂u- (“key, hook, nail”). Cognate with Ancient Greek κλείς (kleís, “bar, bolt, key”), Old High German sliozan (“to close, conclude, lock”), Old Saxon slūtan (“to close, conclude, lock”).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • clūdō

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈklau̯.doː/, [ˈklˠau̯.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈklau̯.do/, [ˈklau̯.d̪ɔ]

Verb[edit]

claudō (present infinitive claudere, perfect active clausī, supine clausum); third conjugation

  1. I shut, close, lock
  2. I imprison, confine
  3. I besiege, blockade
  4. I limit, restrict

Derived terms[edit]
  • circumclūdō
  • clausula
  • clausum
  • clausus
  • conclūdō
  • disclūdō
  • exclūdō
  • inclūdō
  • interclūdō
  • occlūdō
  • praeclūdō
  • reclūdō
  • seclūdō
 
Related terms[edit]
  • claustellum
  • claustra
  • claustrārius
  • claustrum
  • clausūra
  • clāvis
  • clāvus
 
Descendants[edit]
  • Italian: chiudere
  • Old French: clore
    • Middle French: clore
      • French: clore
  • Old Occitan:
    • Catalan: cloure
    • Occitan: claure
  • Old Portuguese: choir, choyr
    • Galician: choer
    • Portuguese: chouver
  • Rhaeto-Romance:
    • Friulian: cludi
  • Sicilian: chiùdiri, chiùjiri, chiùiri, jùjiri
  • ⇒ Latin: clausus, clūsus
    • Italian: chiuso
      • → Serbo-Croatian: ćuza
        • → Albanian: quzë
    • Old French:
      • French: clos
      • Gallo: tio
      • Norman: clios, cliôs, cllos
      • → Middle English: clos (in part)
        • English: close
          • → Irish: clós
          • → Welsh: clos
        • Scots: close
    • Old Occitan:
      • Catalan: clos
      • Occitan: claus
    • Old Portuguese:
      • Galician: chousa
      • Portuguese: chouso
    • Sicilian: chiusu

Etymology 2[edit]

Alternative form of claudeō (“limp”), from claudus (“limping; lame”).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • claudeō

Verb[edit]

claudō (present infinitive claudere, supine clausum); third conjugation, no perfect stem

  1. Alternative form of claudeō

References[edit]

  • claudo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • claudo in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • claudo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • (ambiguous) to turn a deaf ear to, to open one's ears to..: aures claudere, patefacere (e.g. veritati, assentatoribus)
    • (ambiguous) to open, shut the door: ostium, fores aperire, claudere
    • (ambiguous) to bring up the rear: agmen claudere, cogere
    • (ambiguous) to besiege a city: oppidum obsidione claudere
